#Text=CHAPTER VIII
#Text=On a certain afternoon in the early part of

#Text=July , about a month after the fight at the irrigating ditch and the mass meeting at Bonneville , Cedarquist , at the moment opening his mail in his office in San Francisco , was genuinely surprised to receive a visit from Presley .
#Text=“ Well , upon my word , Pres , ” exclaimed the manufacturer , as the young man came in through the door that the office boy held open for him , “ upon my word , have you been sick ?
#Text=Sit down , my boy .
#Text=Have a glass of sherry .
#Text=I always keep a bottle here . ”
#Text=Presley accepted the wine and sank into the depths of a great leather chair near by .
#Text=“ Sick ? ” he answered .
#Text=“ Yes , I have been sick .
#Text=I 'm sick now .
#Text=I 'm gone to pieces , sir . ”
#Text=His manner was the extreme of listlessness -- the listlessness of great fatigue .
#Text=“ Well , well , ” observed the other .
#Text=“ I 'm right sorry to hear that .
#Text=What 's the trouble , Pres ? ”
#Text=“ Oh , nerves mostly , I suppose , and my head , and insomnia , and weakness , a general collapse all along the line , the doctor tells me .
#Text=' Over-cerebration , ' he says ; ' over-excitement .
#Text='
#Text=I fancy I rather narrowly missed brain fever . ”
#Text=“ Well , I can easily suppose it , ” answered Cedarquist gravely , “ after all you have been through . ”
#Text=Presley closed his eyes -- they were sunken in circles of dark brown flesh -- and pressed a thin hand to the back of his head .
#Text=“ It is a nightmare , ” he murmured .
#Text=“ A frightful nightmare , and it 's not over yet .
#Text=You have heard of it all only through the newspaper reports .

#Text=But down there , at Bonneville , at Los Muertos -- oh , you can have no idea of it , of the misery caused by the defeat of the ranchers and by this decision of the Supreme Court that dispossesses them all .
#Text=We had gone on hoping to the last that we would win there .
#Text=We had thought that in the Supreme Court of the United States , at least , we could find justice .
#Text=And the news of its decision was the worst , last blow of all .
#Text=For Magnus it was the last -- positively the very last . ”
#Text=“ Poor , poor Derrick , ” murmured Cedarquist .
#Text=“ Tell me about him , Pres .
#Text=How does he take it ?
#Text=What is he going to do ? ”
#Text=“ It beggars him , sir .
#Text=He sunk a great deal more than any of us believed in his ranch , when he resolved to turn off most of the tenants and farm the ranch himself .
#Text=Then the fight he made against the Railroad in the Courts and the political campaign he went into , to get Lyman on the Railroad Commission , took more of it .
#Text=The money that Genslinger blackmailed him of , it seems , was about all he had left .
#Text=He had been gambling -- you know the Governor -- on another bonanza crop this year to recoup him .
#Text=Well , the bonanza came right enough -- just in time for S. Behrman and the Railroad to grab it .
#Text=Magnus is ruined . ”

#Text=“ What a tragedy ! what a tragedy ! ” murmured the other . “ Lyman turning rascal , Harran killed , and now this ; and all within so short a time -- all at the SAME time , you might almost say . ”
#Text=“ If it had only killed him , ” continued Presley ;
#Text=“ but that is the worst of it . ”
#Text=“ How the worst ? ”
#Text=“ I 'm afraid , honestly , I 'm afraid it is going to turn his wits , sir .
#Text=It 's broken him ; oh , you should see him , you should see him .
#Text=A shambling , stooping , trembling old man , in his dotage already .
#Text=He sits all day in the dining-room , turning over papers , sorting them , tying them up , opening them again , forgetting them -- all fumbling and mumbling and confused .
#Text=And at table sometimes he forgets to eat .
#Text=And , listen , you know , from the house we can hear the trains whistling for the Long Trestle .
#Text=As often as that happens the Governor seems to be -- oh , I do n't know , frightened .
#Text=He will sink his head between his shoulders , as though he were dodging something , and he wo n't fetch a long breath again till the train is out of hearing .
#Text=He seems to have conceived an abject , unreasoned terror of the Railroad . ”
#Text=“ But he will have to leave Los Muertos now , of course ? ”
#Text=“ Yes , they will all have to leave .
#Text=They have a fortnight more .
#Text=The few tenants that were still on Los Muertos are leaving .
#Text=That is one thing that brings me to the city .
#Text=The family of one of the men who was killed --
#Text=Hooven was his name -- have come to the city to find work .
#Text=I think they are liable to be in great distress , unless they have been wonderfully lucky , and I am trying to find them in order to look after them . ”
#Text=“ You need looking after yourself , Pres . ”
#Text=“ Oh , once away from Bonneville and the sight of the ruin there , I 'm better .
#Text=But I intend to go away .
#Text=And that makes me think , I came to ask you if you could help me .
#Text=If you would let me take passage on one of your wheat ships .
#Text=The Doctor says an ocean voyage would set me up . ”
#Text=“ Why , certainly , Pres , ” declared Cedarquist .
#Text=“ But I 'm sorry you 'll have to go .
#Text=We expected to have you down in the country with us this winter . ”
#Text=Presley shook his head .
#Text=“ No , ” he answered .
#Text=“ I must go .
#Text=Even if I had all my health , I could not bring myself to stay in California just now .
#Text=If you can introduce me to one of your captains -- ”
